_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program 1 Risk Management Plan

Emma Owner Pad

Facility ID 1000 0023 1867

WPX Energy, Inc.



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



BFX Energy Solutions operates a portable refrigeration type gas dew point control and liquids recovery skid designed to recover propane, butane and natural gasoline from produced gas prior to gathering and final treatment for WPX Energy, Inc. (WPX) at the Emma Owner Pad. This report provides the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the recovery skid system, pursuant to the requirements of the U.S. EPA RMP rule.



The system is designed to remove liquids from gas at the wellhead. The refrigeration system can operate at subzero temperatures. BFX Energy Solutions uses this system to remove liquids from produced gas prior to flaring. 



Two LPG portable storage tanks will be used for liquid products storage. Each has a maximum capacity of 18,000 gallons. BFX Energy Solutions limits the maximum fill to 90% of the tank volume or 16,200 gallons each. 



For the purpose of this assessment, the LPG storage tanks will be filled to 16,200 gallons, which is equivalent 64,800 lbs. of flammable liquids. The worst case scenario would be is both tanks exploded and the total pounds of flammable liquids used for the analysis is 129,600 lbs. 



Under the authority of section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act, the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions require facilities that produce, handle, process, distribute, or store certain chemicals to develop a Risk Management Program, prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP), and submit the RMP to EPA. Covered facilities were initially required to comply with the rule in 1999, and the rule has been amended on several occasions since then, most recently in 2004. This facility is regulated under Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68), more commonly known as the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. RMP plans must be prepared for processes that store in excess of the thresholds set forth by 40 CFR 68.130. For flammable

liquids, the threshold is 10,000 lbs. BFX Energy Solutions can store approximately 129,600 lbs of LPG and exceeds 10,000 lbs. threshold, thus the facility is subject to the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention rule and must prepare a RMP.



LOCATION



Address:  9637 25th Street NW

Mandaree, ND 58757

NE ? of Section 26, T150N, R94W, McKenzie County, North Dakota

Latitude: 47.785886, Longitude: -102.671036

Driving Directions: Proceed westerly from Mandaree, North Dakota along 22nd Street Northwest. Follow this route for approximately 1.2 miles to the intersection of Highway 22. Turn right onto Highway 22 and continue northerly for approximately 2.8 miles to the intersection of BIA 28. Turn right onto BIA 28 and continue easterly for approximately 3.4 miles to the access road to the Emma Owner 23-14H pad site. Turn left onto access road and continue northwesterly approximately 1.1 miles to the existing well location.



DISPERSION MODELING ANAYSIS WITH RMP*COMP



RMP*Comp: Results of Consequence Analysis

Scenario Summary

February 8, 2016



Chemical Name    CAS Number    Quantity Released (pounds)

Butane             106-97-8    35420

Ethane             74-84-0    100

Isobutane     75-28-5    10653

Isopentane     78-78-4    7465

Pentane             109-66-0    21092

Propane             74-98-6    54870



Threat type:      Flammable

Scenario type:  Worst-case

Release type:   Vapor Cloud Explosion

Estimated distance to 1 psi overpressure: 0.4 miles (0.7 kilometers)



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS: POPULATION AND ENVIRONMENT



After the distance to the flammable endpoint has been determined, the offsite impacts on population, public receptors, and environmental receptors should be analyzed as required by the RMP rule. The population within a circle centered at the point of release and a radius equal to the distance to the flammable endpoint should be estimated to two significant digits. In addition, all types of public receptors (schools, residences, hospitals, prisons, public recr

eation areas or arenas, major commercial or industrial areas) and environmental receptors (national or state parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, or refuges; federal wilderness areas) within this distance should be identified.



A field survey was used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the flammable endpoint and to identify public receptors. The survey showed that no population is within the 0.4 mile impact radius for the worst case release. The impact area on a map is demonstrated in appendix A. The types of public receptors and environmental receptors identified within the impact area are listed in Table 2-2. Google Earth was used to find the public receptors within the impact radius. The distance to the nearest public receptor from the facility is approximately 1.5 miles, which is beyond the 0.4 mile distance to the level of concern. Additionally, no environmental receptors are impacted by the worst-case release scenario.
